questions.question: Do you think there's a actual line to eventually be drawn between life and non-life?
Do you have a sense of where the tiniest thing is that is like at the lowest level?
How important is this distinction between discrete and continuous for you to get to the bottom?
So is the human mind fundamentally more capable as a thinking machine than a universal Turing machine?
But ultimately discovering the suitable hyperparameters of the architecture is also only a search process, right?
What do you do if something doesn't get better, and you want it to get better?
Is it just some weird little quirk, or is there some fundamental expansion of the mind going on?
So what do you think will be the capabilities of GPT-4, GPT-5 and so on?
And what are the values of the person that writes the software and deploys this process?
If you don't have that shared purpose, right, what is there to be ethical for?
Do you think from a historical perspective, Hitler could have been stopped from within Germany or from outside?
So the question is how hard is it to encode, to properly encode the right incentives into the AI?
Or is there significant limitations to what we're able to do in terms of good and evil?
Is it true that when you're a father, you grow immune to the crying and all that kind of stuff?
What in this monkey riding an elephant in a dream world, what role does love play in the human condition?
Do you find meaning in raising children and projecting a multi-generational organism into the future?
